title: Oregon school shooting updates: Umpqua Community College reopens; memorials remember victims
text:
School reopens Monday morning at Umpqua Community College. It's been nearly two weeks since a gunman burst into a classroom and shot to death nine people, injured nine more and killed himself.
The nearby town of Roseburg has been mourning since the Oct. 1 mass shootings. Over the past weekend, the community continued its recovery with memorial services and tributes to the victims and the survivors.
Reporters and photographers from The Oregonian/OregonLive will be near the campus today as teachers and students return. Return to OregonLive for updates throughout the day.
WEEKEND UPDATES:
The night the silence ended in Roseburg: How a football game began the healing of a community by Jason Quick
Roseburg High School students raise money for UCC victims Wanting to do something to help the victims of the Umpqua Community College shooting, a group of Roseburg High School students had t-shirts made that they then distributed in exchange for donations, raising $3000 in two days. Many students and others wore the shirts at Roseburg's first home football game since the tragedy.
To the people who live here, this town has changed in the past week. Oh, things look the same – traffic still snarls on Garden Valley Boulevard and Loggers still serves the best pizza – but it's the sounds that get them. Ever since that awful morning, when shots rang out at Umpqua Community College, their ears tell them something is off.
People don't speak as much. Or as loudly. Music hasn't played as much, or as loudly. And nobody feels much like laughing.
"It's a lot quieter,'' Roseburg High junior Austin Harris said. "The whole town is just ... different. You can feel it.''
So they returned Friday to watch one of the hallmarks of this tight knit logging community: Roseburg High football.
A community 'still hurting' says its goodbyes by Ian K. Kullgren
"We're Gonna Miss Him Forever. He'll Live In Our Hearts Forever." Larry McGraw, family friend of Quinn Glen Cooper, spoke outside before the start of Cooper's memorial. McGraw was Cooper's weight trainer.
They came on motorcycles and in pickup trucks, dozens of them, forming a human perimeter to keep the outsiders out.
As people streamed out of a memorial service Saturday for Quinn Cooper, 18, demonstrators on the sidewalk in front of Roseburg Christian Fellowship used bed sheets to block shots from cameras across the street, though there were fewer visible than last week.
It's been nine days since Umpqua Community College became the backdrop for one of the worst school shootings in U.S. history, joining the heartrending ranks of Columbine, Virginia Tech and Sandy Hook. Nine days since media from all over the world descended on this sleepy timber town, clamoring for interviews, invading church services and shoving microphones in people's faces. Nine days since their home took center stage in the divisive national debate over gun control.
Roseburg's Tapestry Tattoo holds fundraiser for shooting victims, families by Beth Nakamura
Customers began lining up in front of Tapestry Tattoo a little after 8 a.m. Sunday, even though the shop wouldn't begin tattooing until noon. The line quickly swelled to more than 100 people, so owner Chere Hall, 41, started tattooing a little earlier than anticipated, at 11 a.m.
People flocked to the tattoo parlor on Southeast Stephens Street in Roseburg as it held a fundraiser Sunday for victims' families and those who were injured in last week's shooting at Umpqua Community College. Hall, along with tattoo artists Chris Bellville, an employee, and Robbie Mills, who came up from Medford, offered UCC-themed tattoos in exchange for donations.
"We were just thinking about the families and the aftermath and the things that people don't think about," Hall said of the fundraising idea.
Hugs, tissue, compassion to greet campus community upon return to classes by Tony Hernandez , Casey Parks and Rebecca Woolington
Last week, as the first people trickled back onto the Umpqua Community College campus, Mo Nichols and Dorothy Williams stretched out their arms and offered hugs.
Most said yes, they needed one. Boys shyly considered before moving in, too.
"We've had some of the most amazing hugs," said Nichols, a board member of the college's foundation.
"It helps release that edge of emotion," Williams said.
It's been 10 days since the campus became the backdrop for Oregon's deadliest shooting ever and one of the worst school shootings in U.S. history.
On Monday, as most students return to the Roseburg college for the first time, Nichols and Williams will again be there offering hugs. They'll join more than 40 volunteers working around the clock to ensure every Umpqua student and professor has support. Tissues will be in every classroom. Comfort dogs will be available.
Myrtle Creek gathers to remember 2 of their own by Tony Hernandez
As the sun began to set Sunday night in Myrtle Creek, more than 160 community members gathered at a park during a vigil for two women who died from the Oct. 1 shooting at Umpqua Community College.
"Sometimes the worst brings out the best," Mayor Ken Brouillard told a community member holding one of hundreds of religious candles donated by a local business owner.
They gathered for Rebecka Carnes, 18, and Sarena Moore, 44, both students who were loved and remembered. They spoke words of comfort as many in attendance sat or stood silent. Couples embraced. Children behaved.
COMING MONDAY:
College reopens: Umpqua Community College reopens Monday for classes. Find updates at OregonLive.com/roseburg-oregon-school-shooting .
